content: Iowa's supreme court has struck down the law banning gay marriage on the grounds that it is a clear violation of the state Constitution's equal protection clause. The vote was unanimous. In 21 days, Iowa joins Massachusetts and Connecticut in treating all committed couples equally under the law. "http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/04/03/iowa.same.sex/index.html

title: Iowa upholds Constitutional Rights.

content: Wonder of wonders, yeah. Not that there's much of a draw for anyone to go to Iowa. I mean, if I lived in Nebraska, a jaunt across state lines maybe, but otherwise... Massachusetts is much nicer.

content: quote: Originally posted by 19022583: quote: Originally posted by Whirled_Peas: Iowa's supreme court has struck down the law banning gay marriage on the grounds that it is a clear violation of the state Constitution's equal protection clause. The vote was unanimous. In 21 days, Iowa joins Massachusetts and Connecticut in treating all committed couples equally under the law. "http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/04/03/iowa.same.sex/index.html Ya know, of course....that this was a STATE constitution and NOT....the federal constitution. Thank you, Captain Obvious. I said that in the original post. The Iowa State Constitution is the Constitution in question, and seeing as each state also operates as a sovereign entity under their individual state constitutions, each state can work out its own marriage law. Additionally, the US Constitution doesn't say anything about marriage either way, and it's only a matter of time before the DOMA is ruled unconstitutional on the national level.

content: quote: Originally posted by 19022583: OUCH....ya really nailed me there; BUT....what will ya say when DOMA is upheld? I don't believe that the ill-named "Defense of Marriage Act" will be upheld; I sincerely believe that it will be found unconstitutional and overturned. Will it happen tomorrow? No, and in case you didn't notice, I never said when it will be fixed, but it will happen eventually. Just as the Jim Crow laws took years before they were ruled unconstitutional, and years before an Amendment was passed to permit women to vote, it will take time before this is fixed, too. What will I say when DOMA is upheld? I'll say again, "It's only a matter of time."
quote: Originally posted by 19022583: OUCH....ya really nailed me there; BUT....what will ya say when DOMA is upheld?
reply: I don't believe that the ill-named "Defense of Marriage Act" will be upheld; I sincerely believe that it will be found unconstitutional and overturned. Will it happen tomorrow? No, and in case you didn't notice, I never said when it will be fixed, but it will happen eventually. Just as the Jim Crow laws took years before they were ruled unconstitutional, and years before an Amendment was passed to permit women to vote, it will take time before this is fixed, too. What will I say when DOMA is upheld? I'll say again, "It's only a matter of time."
title: Iowa upholds Constitutional Rights.

content: With the Obama administration formally endorsing a U.N. statement calling for the worldwide decriminalization of homosexuality, a measure that former President George W. Bush had refused to sign, I don’t see how the U.S. can justify keeping DOMA much longer.

content: Iowa Gov. Won't Fight Marriage Decision Democratric Iowa governor Chet Culver said that he will not fight the state supreme court's decision on Friday to open marriage rights to gay and lesbian couples. Culver, in a statement issued on Tuesday, said that the state must concentrate on more pressing issues like the economy and the global economic decline. "I urge Iowans who hold beliefs on all sides of this issue to exhibit respect and goodwill," he added. "Our state faces many serious challenges. We are in the midst of a serious economic recession. Tens of thousands of our fellow Iowans are without work. We have suffered the worst natural disasters and most difficult recovery our state has ever faced. We must join together and redouble our efforts to work toward solutions that will help Iowans in this time of uncertainty. That is where, I believe, my focus and energies should lie." >http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid78113.asp

content: I saw an interesting fact in my email inbox today. No state legislator who has voted in favor of gay marriage has been successfully ousted in an election after that vote. Not one. In any state. ALL legislators who have voted in favor of gay marriage have successfully won re-election when sought.

content: Iowa Issues Marriage Licenses To Gays Couples Prepare To Head Down The Aisle As State Becomes 3rd To Allow Same-Sex Marriage (CBS/AP) Same-sex couples in Iowa began applying for marriage licenses on Monday after a state Supreme Court ruling legalizing gay unions took effect. The court issued an order early in the day confirming that the appeals process in the case has officially concluded. Gay marriage opponents have no other legal options to appeal the case to the state or federal level because they were not parties to the lawsuit and there were no federal issues raised in the case. Their only recourse appears to be a constitutional amendment, which couldn't get on the ballot until 2012 at the earliest. A constitutional convention could be called earlier, but that is unlikely. Full article at >>>http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/04/27/national/main4970693.shtml?tag=topHome;topStories

content: April 27, 2009 Prayer Vigils Protest Iowa Same-Sex Marriages On the first day legal same-sex marriages could be performed in Iowa, prayer vigils were held in protest at county courthouses on Monday. Gloria Villaneuva of Bonaparte organized the statewide prayer service to express her opposition to the Iowa supreme court ruling that legalized same-sex marriage earlier this month. Prayer participants were urged to report to their local county courthouse at 7:45 a.m. and join vigils like this one, captured by the Ottumwa Courier. Heavier than usual crowds are expected at Iowa’s 99 county courthouses today, with the largest turnout anticipated in Polk County, Radio Iowa reports. Same-sex couples may wed after a three-day waiting period, or sooner if a waiver is granted. Some county recorders said they would refuse to marry same-sex couples, but the state has ordered them to follow the court’s mandate. Recorders who are opposed threatened to resign. Iowa followed Massachusetts, California, and Connecticut as the fourth state to legalize same-sex marriage -- though California's marriage equality was later thrown into limbo by Prop. 8, currently being contested in the state supreme court. Vermont will be the fifth state to recognize marriage equality, with same-sex marriages set to begin on September 1. >>>http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid80765.asp
